categories.title: Greetings & Expressions
categories.description: Essential greetings, polite phrases, and common everyday expressions

words.proTip: In Portugal, 'bom dia' is used until lunch (around 1–2pm). After that, switch to 'boa tarde'.
In Portugal, switch to 'boa tarde' after lunch (around 1–2pm). Before lunch: 'bom dia.' After dark: 'boa noite.'
Used both as 'good evening' (when arriving) and 'good night' (when leaving). Same phrase for both — context tells you which.
'Adeus' is more final than 'até logo.' Use 'até logo' or 'até amanhã' when you expect to see the person again soon.

words.exampleTranslation: Thank you very much for the help.
words.proTip: Men say 'obrigado,' women say 'obrigada' — it literally means 'obliged.' This is one of the few words in Portuguese where the speaker's gender matters, not the listener's.
Say 'por favor' or 'faz favor' — both work. To call a waiter: 'Faz favor!' or raise your hand. Never snap your fingers.

words.exampleTranslation: Excuse me, where is the metro?
words.proTip: 'Desculpe' works both for getting attention ('Excuse me, where is...?') and for apologizing. To pass through a crowd, use 'com licença.'

words.exampleTranslation: Maybe I'll go to the cinema.

words.proTip: 'Claro!' or 'Claro que sim!' = Of course! Also means 'clear' (o céu está claro = the sky is clear).
'Com licença' is for passing through. 'Desculpe' is for getting attention or apologizing. To call a waiter, say 'Faz favor!' — never snap your fingers.
For birthdays: 'Parabéns!' or 'Parabéns pelo aniversário!' Also used for congratulations ( exams, new job).
Say 'Saúde!' when someone sneezes. When toasting drinks, Portuguese often say 'Saúde!' or 'Tim-tim!' (clink). The word also means 'health' as a noun.
'Pois' is a very Portuguese filler word — it means 'indeed,' 'right,' or 'well' depending on context. Used when agreeing: 'Pois, tens razão.'
'Fixe' is THE word for 'cool' in Portugal. 'Que fixe!' = How cool! 'Bué fixe' = Super cool. It's informal but used by all ages. Never say 'legal' for cool — that's Brazilian.
Multi-use word: 'Pronto!' = Done! / Okay! / Ready! Also used to wrap up: 'Pronto, vou embora' = Right, I'm going.
Use 'como estás?' with friends and family (informal). For formal situations, use 'como está?' (você form).

words.exampleTranslation: How's it going? Long time no see!

words.proTip: 'Até logo' = see you later (same day). 'Até já' = see you in a moment. 'Até amanhã' = see you tomorrow.
Common goodbye. 'Amanhã' = tomorrow. Respond with 'Até amanhã!' or 'Até lá!'

words.exampleTranslation: I'm going over there, see you in a sec!
words.proTip: 'Até já' means you'll see the person very soon (minutes). 'Até logo' is for later the same day.

words.exampleTranslation: You're welcome, it was a pleasure.
words.proTip: 'De nada' is the standard response to 'obrigado/obrigada.' 'Não há de quê' is a slightly more formal alternative.

words.exampleTranslation: Nice to meet you, I'm Rui.
words.proTip: In Portugal, people typically shake hands when meeting for the first time. Say 'Muito prazer' and your name. The other person usually replies 'Igualmente' or 'Também.'
Reply to 'Bom fim de semana!' or 'Muito prazer' — 'Igualmente!' = Likewise! / Same to you!
To call a waiter in Portugal, say 'Faz favor!' or raise your hand slightly — never snap your fingers. 'Um café, faz favor' = A coffee, please.
Say before exams, interviews, trips: 'Boa sorte!' Reply: 'Obrigado!' or 'Obrigada!'
In Portugal, say 'Bom apetite!' or 'Bom proveito!' before starting a meal. It's polite and expected — don't start eating until someone says it or until everyone is served.
Reassuring: 'Não faz mal' = No worries / It doesn't matter. Like 'de nada' but for apologies. 'Desculpa!' — 'Não faz mal.'

categories.title: Numbers & Time
categories.description: Counting, telling time, days of the week, and temporal expressions

words.exampleTranslation: The rent is one thousand euros.

words.proTip: 'Que horas são?' = What time is it? Portugal uses both 12h and 24h time. For 'it's 3pm' say 'São três da tarde' or 'São quinze horas.' Always feminine: 'É uma hora' (it's 1 o'clock).
'Um minuto' = one minute, or 'wait a moment.' 'Espera um minuto' = Wait a minute. Often said when busy.
Pronunciation: 'OH-zhuh' — the 'j' sounds like French 'j' or 's' in 'measure.' Not like English 'j'.

words.exampleTranslation: Tomorrow I'm going to the doctor.

words.proTip: 'A próxima semana' = next week. 'Semana que vem' = the coming week. 'Na semana passada' = last week.
Pronunciation: 'MAYSH' — like 'mes' in 'mesmerize' but with a slight 'sh' at the end. Plural: 'meses.'
'Tenho vinte anos' = I am twenty years old. The word 'anos' (years) is masculine, unlike English where we say 'years old.'

words.exampleTranslation: In the morning I have coffee.
words.proTip: Feminine: 'a manhã.' 'De manhã' = in the morning. 'Esta manhã' = this morning. Note: 'manhã' vs 'amanhã' (tomorrow).

words.exampleTranslation: In the afternoon I go running.
words.proTip: 'Tarde' has two meanings: 'afternoon' (feminine noun) and 'late' (adverb). 'Cheguei tarde' = I arrived late. Different stress in speech.

words.exampleTranslation: In the evening I watch television.
words.proTip: Feminine: 'a noite.' 'À noite' = at night / in the evening. 'Boa noite' = good evening / good night.
A-goh-rah. Common: 'Agora não' = Not now. 'Agora mesmo' = Right now. 'Até agora' = Until now.
'Depois' = later / after. 'Falamos depois' = We'll talk later. 'Depois do jantar' = After dinner.
'Antes' = before. 'Antes de' + infinitive. 'Antes do jantar' = Before dinner. Opposite of 'depois.'
Sempre = always. 'Sempre' before the verb: 'Ela sempre chega tarde' = She always arrives late.
'Nunca' comes before the verb: 'Nunca fui' = I've never been. 'Não... nunca' = never (double negative is normal in Portuguese).
Às vezes = sometimes. 'Às vezes como fora' = Sometimes I eat out. Note the 'às' (contraction).
'Cedo' = early (adverb). 'De manhã cedo' = early in the morning. Don't confuse with 'cedo' in 'até logo' — different context.
Tarde = afternoon (noun) OR late (adverb). 'Cheguei tarde' = I arrived late. Context matters!

words.exampleTranslation: Meanwhile, you can set the table.
In the old days there were no mobile phones.
On Monday I'm going to the doctor.
words.proTip: Weekdays in Portugal: segunda, terça, quarta, quinta, sexta. All take 'feira' — from the old market days.

words.example: À terça-feira tenho aula de português.
words.exampleTranslation: On Tuesday I have Portuguese class.
On Thursday I have dinner out.
On Saturday I go to the beach.
words.proTip: Sábado = Saturday. Masculine. 'Ao sábado' = on Saturday. Weekend starts here!

words.exampleTranslation: On Sunday I rest at home.
words.proTip: Domingo = Sunday. Traditional family day — almoço with parents/grandparents.

words.example: O que vais fazer no fim de semana?
words.exampleTranslation: What are you going to do at the weekend?
words.proTip: In Portugal, 'fim de semana' (literally 'end of week') is Saturday and Sunday. Say 'Bom fim de semana!' on Fridays.

words.example: Vou ao ginásio uma vez por semana.
words.exampleTranslation: I go to the gym once a week.

words.example: Tomo café duas vezes por dia.
words.exampleTranslation: I have coffee twice a day.
I'll arrive in a quarter of an hour.
We arrived in the early hours.
words.proTip: 'De madrugada' = in the early hours (roughly 2–6am). Portuguese nightlife often goes 'até de madrugada' — until the small hours.
Meio-dia = noon. 'O almoço é ao meio-dia' — Portuguese lunch is often 12:30–2pm.
Meia-noite = midnight. 'À meia-noite' = at midnight. Feminine.

words.exampleTranslation: The day before yesterday I went to the dentist.
I'm travelling the day after tomorrow.
We'll be back in a fortnight.

words.example: O castelo é do século XV.
words.exampleTranslation: The castle is from the 15th century.

words.proTip: Feriado = public holiday. Shops closed, families together. 'Amanhã é feriado.'

words.exampleTranslation: Excuse me, what time is it?
words.proTip: Portugal uses 24h time in writing. In speech: 'São três da tarde' or 'São quinze horas.' Always feminine: 'É uma hora.'

categories.title: Colours & Weather
categories.description: Colours, weather conditions, and seasonal vocabulary

words.proTip: Colour adjectives agree: 'carro vermelho' (m), 'casa vermelha' (f). In Portugal, red wine = vinho tinto.
Agrees with noun: 'céu azul,' 'camisa azul' (blue is invariable — ends in consonant).
Portuguese love verde — parks, countryside, 'verde' symbolises nature. 'Pôr a verde' = to criticise severely.
Amarelo (yellow) — the -o/-a agreement: 'sol amarelo,' 'casa amarela.'
Vinho branco = white wine. 'Em branco' = blank. Branco (white) agrees: branco/branca.
Café preto = black coffee (no milk). Preto agrees: preto/preta.
Castanho = brown. Common for eyes: 'olhos castanhos.' Also chestnut — castanhas in autumn.
Invariable — doesn't change for gender: 'camisa cor-de-rosa,' 'casaco cor-de-rosa.'
Roxo (purple) — 'roxo' can also mean bruised: 'joelho roxo' = bruised knee.
O dia está cinzento = The day is grey. Portuguese use this a lot for cloudy Lisbon weather.
'Está sol' = It's sunny. In Portugal the sun can be strong — say 'protector solar' for sunscreen.
In Lisbon, rain can come suddenly. 'Está a chover' = It's raining. Always carry an 'guarda-chuva' in winter.
Portugal's coast is windy — 'Está muito vento' = It's very windy. Norte (north wind) brings cold.
'Está frio' = It's cold. Portuguese homes can feel cold in winter — heating isn't always central.
'Está quente' = It's hot (weather). 'A água está quente' = The water is hot. Quente is invariable.

words.example: O céu está cheio de nuvens.
words.exampleTranslation: The sky is full of clouds.
words.proTip: Feminine: a nuvem, nuvens. 'O céu está cheio de nuvens' = The sky is full of clouds.
Rare in Lisbon — 'Nunca neva aqui.' In Serra da Estrela they have snow. Feminine.
Trovoada = thunderstorm. 'Há trovoada' = There's a thunderstorm. Summer storms are common.
Ask: 'Qual é a temperatura?' Portugal uses Celsius. 25° = 'vinte e cinco graus.'

words.example: A previsão do tempo diz que vai chover.
words.exampleTranslation: The weather forecast says it will rain.
words.proTip: Check 'previsão do tempo' on TV or IPMA.pt. Portuguese love talking about weather.

words.example: O pôr do sol está laranja.
words.proTip: 'Laranja' = both the fruit (orange) and the colour. Same word in EP and BR.
Dourado = golden. 'Luz dourada' = golden light. Common for sunset descriptions.
Prateado = silver. Often for cars: 'carro prateado.'
Verde escuro = dark green. Escuro agrees: escuro/escura.
'Claro' = light (colour) or 'of course!' Don't confuse: 'verde claro' = light green; 'Claro que sim!' = Of course!

words.exampleTranslation: There's a lot of fog in the morning.
words.proTip: Common in Lisbon mornings, especially near the river. 'Há muito nevoeiro' = There's a lot of fog.
Tempestade = storm. 'Vem aí uma tempestade' = A storm is coming. Stay indoors.
Chuvisco = drizzle. Portuguese drizzle (brisa) is typical — light rain, no umbrella needed sometimes.
Granizo = hail. Rare but happens. 'Caiu granizo' = It hailed.
March–June. Best time to visit — flowers, mild weather. 'Na primavera' = in spring.

words.exampleTranslation: In summer we go to the beach.
words.proTip: June–September. Hot and dry. 'No verão' = in summer. Beach season.

words.example: O outono é a minha estação preferida.
words.proTip: September–December. 'No outono' = in autumn. Castanhas (chestnuts) and vindima (grape harvest).
December–March. 'No inverno' = in winter. Rainy, cold, but rarely freezing in Lisbon.

words.example: Qual é a tua estação do ano preferida?
words.proTip: As quatro estações = the four seasons. Primavera, verão, outono, inverno.

words.example: O clima em Lisboa é húmido.
words.exampleTranslation: The climate in Lisbon is humid.
words.proTip: Portugal spells it 'húmido' (with h), not 'úmido' — that's Brazilian. Lisbon's climate can be húmido, especially near the river.
'Está calor' (impersonal) = It's hot. Don't say 'eu estou calor' — wrong. 'Tenho calor' = I'm hot.
'Está frio' = It's cold. 'Tenho frio' = I'm cold (personal). Portuguese homes can feel cold in winter.

words.example: Leva o guarda-chuva, está a chover.
words.proTip: Present continuous: estar a + infinitive. 'Está a chover' = It's raining. Very common structure in EP.
Literally 'rain guard.' Essential in Lisbon winters. 'Leva o guarda-chuva' = Take the umbrella.

words.example: Está bom tempo para um passeio.
words.exampleTranslation: The weather is nice for a walk.
words.proTip: 'Está bom tempo' = The weather is nice. Perfect for 'Vamos dar um passeio?' (Shall we go for a walk?).

categories.title: Food & Drink
categories.description: Restaurants, grocery shopping, cooking, and common ingredients

words.example: Uma garrafa de água, por favor.
words.proTip: At restaurants, specify 'com gás' or 'sem gás' — otherwise you might get whichever they have. Tap water ('água da torneira') is safe to drink in Portugal but not always offered.

words.exampleTranslation: I want a coffee with milk.
words.proTip: In Lisbon, order a 'bica' for espresso. In Porto, say 'cimbalino.' A 'café' works everywhere. 'Um café, por favor' is probably the most useful sentence in Portugal.
In Portugal it's 'sumo' (juice), not 'suco' (Brazilian). 'Sumo de laranja natural' = fresh orange juice.
Order 'uma imperial' for a small draft beer (the standard size). 'Uma caneca' = a pint-sized mug.
Bread is sacred in Portugal. At restaurants, bread and olives ('couvert') often appear automatically — but they're not free! You can politely decline.

words.exampleTranslation: In Portugal we eat a lot of fish.
words.proTip: Peixe = fish. Same singular/plural in some contexts. Portugal eats a lot of peixe — coastal nation.

words.example: O bacalhau à Brás é típico.
words.proTip: Bacalhau (salt cod) is Portugal's national dish — there are hundreds of recipes. Always soaked before cooking to remove salt.
Portuguese often start lunch with soup — 'sopa de legumes' or 'caldo verde' (kale soup). It's a staple.

words.example: A maçã é a minha fruta preferida.
words.exampleTranslation: The apple is my favourite fruit.

words.proTip: 'Laranja' = both the fruit (orange) and the colour. Same word in EP and BR.

words.exampleTranslation: Sauté the onion in olive oil.
Portuguese olive oil is the best.

words.proTip: Order coffee: 'com açúcar' or 'sem açúcar.' Many Portuguese drink 'café sem açúcar' — bitter is the norm.

words.example: Uma tosta de presunto e queijo.
words.exampleTranslation: A toasted sandwich with ham and cheese.
words.proTip: Presunto = cured ham (like prosciutto). Fiambre = cooked ham for sandwiches. Presunto is a Portuguese delicacy.

words.example: Os pastéis de nata de Belém.
words.proTip: Portugal's iconic custard tart. Best warm with cinnamon. The original is from Belém — 'pastéis de Belém.'
Always say 'pequeno-almoço' in Portugal, never 'café da manhã' (that's Brazilian). A typical Portuguese breakfast is a galão (milky coffee) with a tosta mista (toasted ham and cheese).
Portuguese lunch is usually 12:30–2pm. Many restaurants have 'prato do dia' (dish of the day) — cheap and good.
In Portugal it's 'ementa' or 'carta' for menu, not 'cardápio' (Brazilian). 'Posso ver a ementa?' = May I see the menu?
Say 'A conta, por favor' to ask for the bill. Tipping in Portugal is appreciated but not obligatory — rounding up or leaving 5-10% is common.

words.exampleTranslation: I'm going to roast the chicken.
Don't fry with too much oil.
Do you have the cake recipe?

words.proTip: Portuguese love piri-piri (chilli sauce). 'Não é picante?' = Isn't it spicy? Chicken piri-piri is a classic.
Petiscos = Portuguese tapas. Order a few with beer or wine at a tasca. 'Uma tasca' = a casual tavern.
Portugal has excellent seafood. 'Arroz de marisco' and 'cataplana' are classics. Always ask 'está fresco?' = is it fresh?

words.exampleTranslation: I buy bread at the bakery.
words.proTip: Pastelaria = café + pastries. Padaria = bakery (mainly bread). Many places are both. Buy 'pão quente' in the morning.

words.example: Uma sandes de fiambre e queijo.
words.proTip: Fiambre = cooked ham (for sandwiches). Presunto = cured ham. Don't confuse — fiambre is cheaper, presunto is a delicacy.

words.example: O bolo de aniversário está na mesa.
words.exampleTranslation: The birthday cake is on the table.
I'd like a table for two.
words.proTip: Say 'Queria uma mesa para dois' when entering. For a table outside: 'Há mesa lá fora?'

words.exampleTranslation: I'm hungry, shall we have dinner?
I'm thirsty, is there any water?
I left a tip on the table.

words.proTip: Say 'Sou vegetariano/a' — Portugal has good veggie options. 'Tem opções vegetarianas?' = Do you have vegetarian options?

words.example: Qual é o prato do dia?
words.exampleTranslation: What is the dish of the day?
words.proTip: The 'prato do dia' is usually cheaper and good value. Ask 'Qual é o prato do dia?'
Say 'Para levar' for takeaway. At a pastelaria: 'Dois cafés, para levar, se faz favor.'

categories.title: Travel & Directions
categories.description: Transport, hotels, asking for help, and getting around

words.proTip: Lisbon airport is officially 'Aeroporto Humberto Delgado' but locals just say 'o aeroporto.' You'll hear 'porta de embarque' for boarding gate.

words.example: Apanhei o comboio para o Porto.
words.exampleTranslation: I caught the train to Porto.
words.proTip: 'Comboio' is European Portuguese — never say 'trem' (that's Brazilian). The CP (Comboios de Portugal) runs the national rail network.
'Autocarro' is strictly PT-PT. In Brazil they say 'ônibus.' In Lisbon, use the Carris network; intercity buses are run by Rede Expressos.

words.example: A estação de metro é aqui perto.

words.proTip: Uber and Bolt work in Lisbon and Porto. Traditional táxis use meters. From the airport, agree on price or use the meter.

words.example: Ando de bicicleta todos os dias.
words.exampleTranslation: I ride a bicycle every day.
We take the boat to Cacilhas.

words.proTip: The famous Eléctrico 28 runs through Lisbon's historic neighborhoods. Locals pronounce it 'eh-LEK-tree-koo' with the accent on the second syllable.

words.exampleTranslation: Where do I buy the ticket?
words.proTip: In Lisbon, most people use a 'Viva Viagem' rechargeable card rather than single bilhetes. 'Passe mensal' is the monthly pass.

words.example: Um bilhete de ida e volta.
words.proTip: At the bilheteira (ticket office), say 'Um bilhete de ida e volta para...' for a return, or 'Só ida' for one-way.

words.example: A hora de partida é às seis.
words.exampleTranslation: The departure time is at six.

words.example: O comboio tem vinte minutos de atraso.
words.exampleTranslation: The train is twenty minutes late.
words.proTip: CP trains can have delays. 'O comboio tem atraso' = The train is delayed. Check cp.pt for updates.

words.example: A Avenida da Liberdade é bonita.

words.exampleTranslation: Do you have a city map?
I booked a hotel in the centre.

words.example: Tenho uma reserva em nome de Silva.
words.exampleTranslation: I have a booking under the name Silva.

words.example: A chave do quarto, por favor.

words.exampleTranslation: Let's go to the beach tomorrow.

words.example: A igreja é do século XV.
words.exampleTranslation: The church is from the 15th century.

words.proTip: Castelo de São Jorge in Lisbon has stunning views. 'Castelo' is masculine: o castelo.

words.exampleTranslation: I'm going to the market to buy fruit.
words.proTip: Mercado da Ribeira (Time Out) in Lisbon is famous. Traditional mercados are cheaper for fresh produce.

words.example: Onde é a farmácia mais próxima?
words.proTip: Portuguese pharmacies (marked with a green cross) can advise on minor ailments without a doctor's visit. There's always a 'farmácia de serviço' open 24h in each area — check the posted schedule on any pharmacy door.

words.exampleTranslation: I need to go to the bank.

words.example: Vou aos correios enviar uma carta.
words.exampleTranslation: I'm going to the post office to send a letter.

words.proTip: Supermercado = supermarket. Pingo Doce, Continente, Lidl are main chains. 'Fazer compras.'

words.exampleTranslation: I'm lost, can you help me?

words.example: Chame uma ambulância, é uma emergência!
words.exampleTranslation: Call an ambulance, it's an emergency!
words.proTip: Emergency number in Portugal: 112. Works for police, fire, ambulance. It's free from any phone.

Portugal's most famous word — there's no exact English translation. 'Tenho saudades tuas' = I miss you. It's deeper than missing; it's a bittersweet longing. Central to Portuguese culture and fado music.

words.example: Qual é a taxa de câmbio?
Na rotunda, toma a segunda saída.
words.exampleTranslation: At the roundabout, take the second exit.
words.proTip: Portugal has many roundabouts (rotundas). 'Na rotunda, toma a segunda saída' = At the roundabout, take the second exit.

words.example: Desculpe, estou perdido. Onde fica a estação?
words.exampleTranslation: Sorry, I'm lost. Where is the station?
words.proTip: Men say 'estou perdido,' women 'estou perdida' — the adjective agrees with the speaker. 'Desculpe, estou perdido. Onde fica...?'

words.example: Pode ajudar-me? Não encontro a rua.
words.exampleTranslation: Can you help me? I can't find the street.
How much does the ticket cost?

words.example: Onde fica a casa de banho?
words.proTip: Essential phrase: 'Onde fica...?' = Where is...? 'Onde fica a estação?' = Where is the station? Add 'por favor' for politeness.

words.example: A que horas parte o comboio?
words.exampleTranslation: What time does the train leave?

words.example: Quero comprar um bilhete para Lisboa.
words.exampleTranslation: I want to buy a ticket to Lisbon.
The bus stop is over there.

words.example: Onde está o horário dos autocarros?

words.exampleTranslation: Is the museum far from here?

categories.title: Home & Rooms
categories.description: Types of housing, rooms, furniture, appliances, and household items

words.proTip: 'Em casa' = at home (no article). 'Na casa' = in the house (specific). 'Estou em casa' = I'm home.
Sala = living room. 'Sala de estar' = sitting room. Central to Portuguese homes — where guests sit.

words.example: O quarto tem uma janela grande.
words.exampleTranslation: The bedroom has a big window.

words.example: Onde é a casa de banho?
words.proTip: In Portugal it's always 'casa de banho,' never 'banheiro' (that's Brazilian and sounds odd in Portugal). In a restaurant, ask 'Onde é a casa de banho?'

words.exampleTranslation: I have coffee on the balcony.
words.proTip: Varanda = balcony. Many Lisbon flats have one. 'Tomar café na varanda' = have coffee on the balcony.

words.exampleTranslation: The car is in the garage.

words.proTip: Escadas = stairs. Feminine plural. 'Moro no 3º andar' = I live on 3rd floor — no elevator in old buildings.

words.example: Põe a mesa para o jantar.

words.exampleTranslation: I'm going to sit on the sofa.
The clothes are in the wardrobe.
Look at yourself in the mirror.
I forgot my phone at home.
words.proTip: 'Telemóvel' is PT-PT — never say 'celular' (that's Brazilian). From 'tele' (distant) + 'móvel' (mobile). Portugal's main operators are MEO, NOS, and Vodafone.
Porta = door. 'Bater à porta' = to knock on the door. 'Porta aberta' = open door (welcoming).
Janela = window. 'Abrir a janela' = open the window. Portuguese love fresh air.

words.example: Põe a máquina de lavar a trabalhar.

words.exampleTranslation: The milk is in the fridge.

words.proTip: Fogão = stove. Many Portuguese cook on gas (gás). 'Cuidado com o fogão' = careful with the stove.

words.example: A renda é cara em Lisboa.
words.exampleTranslation: The rent is expensive in Lisbon.
words.proTip: Renda = rent (the payment). 'A renda é cara em Lisboa' = Rent is expensive in Lisbon. Pay 'no início do mês' = at the start of the month.

words.exampleTranslation: The boxes are in the attic.
The wine is in the cellar.
words.proTip: Cave = basement or wine cellar. Portuguese often keep wine 'na cave.'

words.exampleTranslation: I live on the third floor.

words.proTip: Vizinhança = neighbourhood. Portuguese often know their neighbours — community matters.

words.exampleTranslation: Fry the egg in the frying pan.
Put it in the oven at 180 degrees.

words.proTip: Micro-ondas = microwave. 'Aquecer no micro-ondas' = heat in the microwave.

words.exampleTranslation: The dishes are in the sink.
The cutlery is in the drawer.
The glasses are on the shelf.

words.example: O sabonete está ao lado do lavatório.
words.exampleTranslation: The soap is next to the sink.

words.example: Onde está a minha escova de dentes?

words.exampleTranslation: I'm going to take a quick shower.
words.proTip: In Portugal: 'tomar banho' = to have a shower/bath. 'Vou tomar um duche' = I'm going to take a shower. Never 'tomar uma ducha' (Brazilian).

words.example: A casa de banho tem banheira.

words.exampleTranslation: Wash your hands at the sink.

words.example: O secador de cabelo está na gaveta.
words.exampleTranslation: The hair dryer is in the drawer.
In winter I use a blanket.

words.example: O livro está na mesinha de cabeceira.
words.exampleTranslation: The book is on the bedside table.

words.proTip: Candeeiro = lamp. 'Acender o candeeiro' = turn on the lamp. Portuguese use candeeiros, not just ceiling lights.

words.exampleTranslation: The alarm goes off at seven.
words.proTip: Despertador = alarm clock. 'O despertador toca às sete' = The alarm goes off at seven.

words.exampleTranslation: The books are on the bookshelf.

words.example: Onde está o comando da televisão?
O quadro na parede é bonito.
words.exampleTranslation: The painting on the wall is beautiful.

words.example: Onde está a chave de casa?
O meu vizinho é muito simpático.
A renda é paga no início do mês.
words.exampleTranslation: The rent is paid at the start of the month.

words.example: Vamos mudar de casa no próximo mês.

words.exampleTranslation: I live on the third floor.
words.proTip: Andar = floor/storey. 'Moro no 3º andar' = I live on the 3rd floor. Ground = rés-do-chão.

categories.title: Family & Daily Routine
categories.description: Family members, relationships, and everyday routines

words.proTip: Mãe = mother. 'A minha mãe' — mãe is feminine. In Portugal, family names: mother's surname often comes last.
Pai = father. Portuguese fathers traditionally had authority; modern families are more equal.

words.example: Os meus pais vivem no Porto.
words.proTip: Pais = parents (plural of pai in this sense). 'Os meus pais' = my parents. Don't confuse with país (country).

words.example: A minha filha tem cinco anos.
words.exampleTranslation: My daughter is five years old.
words.proTip: Filho/filha = son/daughter. 'Tenho um filho' = I have a son. Used for children of any age.
Irmão/irmã = brother/sister. 'Meus irmãos' can mean brothers or siblings (mixed).

words.example: A minha avó faz o melhor bolo.
words.exampleTranslation: My grandmother makes the best cake.
words.proTip: Avó (grandmother) vs avô (grandfather) — the accent changes the sound. Avó = ah-VOH, avô = ah-VAW. Easy to mix up!

words.example: O meu tio vive em Coimbra.
words.proTip: Tio/tia = uncle/aunt. Portuguese families are often close — 'almoço de família' on Sundays.

words.example: A minha prima casa em junho.
words.exampleTranslation: My cousin is getting married in June.
words.proTip: Primo/prima = cousin. 'Primos em segundo grau' = second cousins.
Marido = husband. 'O meu marido' — common in all contexts.
'Mulher' = woman or wife. 'A minha mulher' = my wife. 'Esposa' is more formal. Both are used in Portugal.

words.example: A minha namorada é de Lisboa.
words.proTip: Namorado/namorada = boyfriend/girlfriend. More serious than 'amigo' — implies romantic relationship.

words.example: Vou sair com os meus amigos.
words.exampleTranslation: I'm going out with my friends.
words.proTip: Amigo/amiga = friend. Portuguese value friendship deeply. 'Os meus amigos' = my friends.

words.exampleTranslation: I wake up at seven in the morning.
words.proTip: Acordar = to wake up. 'Acordo às sete' = I wake up at seven. Reflexive optional in EP.
Levantar-se = to get up. 'Levanto-me cedo' = I get up early. The 'me' is the reflexive pronoun.
Tomar banho = to have a shower/bath. Never 'tomar uma ducha' (Brazilian). 'Tomei banho' = I showered.
Vestir-se = to get dressed. 'Visto-me depressa' = I get dressed quickly.

words.exampleTranslation: I leave the house at eight.
words.proTip: Sair de casa = to leave the house. 'Saio de casa às oito' = I leave at eight.
Trabalhar = to work. 'Trabalho em casa' = I work from home. Portuguese work long hours by EU standards.
Descansar = to rest. 'Preciso de descansar' = I need to rest. Sunday is often family rest day.

words.exampleTranslation: I sleep eight hours a night.
words.proTip: Dormir = to sleep. Irregular: durmo, dormes, dorme. 'Durmo oito horas' = I sleep eight hours.

words.exampleTranslation: I go to bed at midnight.
words.proTip: Deitar-se = to go to bed. 'Deito-me à meia-noite' = I go to bed at midnight.

words.exampleTranslation: I'm going to clean the house.
words.proTip: Limpar = to clean. 'Limpar a casa' = to clean the house. Saturday morning is often limpeza day.

words.exampleTranslation: I'm going to wash the clothes.
words.proTip: Lavar = to wash. 'Lavar a loiça' = wash the dishes. 'Lavar a roupa' = do the laundry.
Arrumar = to tidy. 'Arruma o teu quarto!' = Tidy your room! (parent to child).

words.example: O meu sobrinho fez dois anos.
A minha sogra cozinha muito bem.
O meu cunhado é do Porto.
O meu padrinho deu-me um relógio.
words.exampleTranslation: My godfather gave me a watch.

words.example: Ela tem uma enteada de dez anos.
words.proTip: Enteado/enteada = stepson/stepdaughter. Blended families use this. 'O meu enteado' = my stepson.

words.exampleTranslation: I've been married for five years.
I comb my hair in front of the mirror.
words.proTip: Pentear-se = to comb one's hair. 'Penteio-me' = I comb my hair.
Barbear-se = to shave. 'Barbeio-me' = I shave. Or use 'fazer a barba.'

words.example: Faço a cama todos os dias.
words.exampleTranslation: I make the bed every day.
words.proTip: Fazer a cama = to make the bed. 'Faço a cama todos os dias' = I make the bed every day.
Pôr a mesa = to set the table. 'Põe a mesa para o jantar' = Set the table for dinner.
Levantar a mesa = to clear the table. Often followed by 'lavar a loiça.'
Passar a ferro = to iron. 'Passar a ferro a roupa' — Portuguese often iron everything, even jeans.
Men say 'atrasado,' women 'atrasada' — the adjective agrees with the speaker. 'Desculpa, estou atrasada!' is common.

words.exampleTranslation: I'm very sleepy, I'm going to sleep.
words.proTip: Tenho sono = I'm sleepy. Different from 'estou cansado' (tired). 'Tenho' + noun for states.

words.example: O que vais fazer no fim de semana?
words.exampleTranslation: What are you going to do at the weekend?
words.proTip: Fim de semana = weekend. 'O que vais fazer no fim de semana?' — common Friday question.
Feriado = public holiday. Portugal has ~13. Shops may be closed. 'É feriado amanhã.'

words.example: As coisas melhoram dia a dia.
words.exampleTranslation: Things get better day by day.
words.proTip: Dia a dia = day to day, daily. 'Vivo dia a dia' = I live day to day.

categories.title: Work & Education
categories.description: Office, school, professions, and workplace vocabulary

words.example: O meu professor de português é simpático.
words.proTip: Professor/professora = teacher. University teachers are also 'professor.' Very respected profession.

words.exampleTranslation: I need to go to the doctor.
words.proTip: In Portugal, go to 'centro de saúde' for GP. For emergency: 'urgências' at hospital. Private: 'clínica.'

words.exampleTranslation: The nurse took my blood pressure.

words.example: O cozinheiro fez um prato excelente.
words.exampleTranslation: The chef made an excellent dish.
She is a journalist at a newspaper.
The firefighters put out the fire.

words.example: Chamei o canalizador para a fuga.
words.exampleTranslation: I called the plumber for the leak.

words.example: O empregado de mesa trouxe a ementa.
words.proTip: In Portugal: 'empregado de mesa' or 'empregado' — never 'garçom' (Brazilian). To call: 'Faz favor!' or raise your hand.

words.example: O motorista do autocarro foi simpático.

words.exampleTranslation: I work in an office in the centre.
words.proTip: 'Escritório' is the physical office. 'Trabalho' is work in general. 'Vou para o escritório' (I'm going to the office) vs 'Vou trabalhar' (I'm going to work).
Empresa = company. 'Trabalhar numa empresa' = to work for a company. PME = small/medium enterprise.

words.exampleTranslation: I have a meeting at ten.
words.proTip: Reunião = meeting. 'Tenho uma reunião' = I have a meeting. Often long in Portugal!
Computador = computer. 'Portátil' = laptop. Portuguese workplaces are increasingly digital.

words.example: O ecrã do portátil é grande.

words.proTip: Email = email. Pronounced 'ee-MAYL.' 'Enviei-te um email' = I sent you an email.
Colega = colleague. Same for m/f! 'Os meus colegas' = my colleagues. Important in work culture.

words.example: O meu chefe aprovou o projeto.
words.proTip: Chefe = boss. Same for m/f. 'O meu chefe' or 'A minha chefe.' Formal hierarchy in many companies.

words.example: O salário é pago no fim do mês.
words.exampleTranslation: The salary is paid at the end of the month.

words.example: Tenho uma entrevista de emprego amanhã.
words.exampleTranslation: I have a job interview tomorrow.

words.example: Qual é o teu horário de trabalho?
Os miúdos vão à escola de autocarro.
words.exampleTranslation: The children go to school by bus.
words.proTip: In Portugal: 'escola' = school; 'universidade' = university. Kids go to escola, adults to universidade or 'faculdade' (faculty).

words.exampleTranslation: I studied at the University of Lisbon.
words.proTip: Universidade = university. Free for EU citizens in public unis. Lisbon, Porto, Coimbra are top.

words.example: A aula de português é às três.
words.exampleTranslation: The Portuguese class is at three.
words.proTip: Aula = class/lesson. 'A aula de português' = the Portuguese class. 'Ter aulas' = to have classes.

words.exampleTranslation: I have an exam on Friday.
words.proTip: Exame = exam. 'Fazer um exame' = to sit an exam. 'Boa sorte no exame!'
Aluno/aluna = student. 'Sou aluno de português' = I'm a Portuguese student.
Livro = book. 'Ler um livro' = to read a book. Livraria = bookshop (different from biblioteca).

words.exampleTranslation: I write the notes in the notebook.
words.proTip: Caderno = notebook. Students use cadernos. 'Escrever no caderno' = to write in the notebook.

words.exampleTranslation: Do you have a pen for me?
words.proTip: Caneta = pen. 'Tens uma caneta?' = Do you have a pen? Caneta de feltro = marker.

words.exampleTranslation: The backpack is in the living room.
I'm going to the library to study.
words.proTip: Biblioteca = library. Free to use. 'Estudar na biblioteca' = to study at the library.

words.exampleTranslation: Look it up in the dictionary.

words.proTip: Curso = course. 'Fiz um curso de português' = I did a Portuguese course. Curso intensivo = intensive.

words.exampleTranslation: I got a good grade in the exam.

words.example: Já fiz o trabalho de casa.
words.proTip: Literally 'house work' — homework. 'Já fiz o trabalho de casa?' = Have you done your homework?

words.exampleTranslation: The teacher wrote on the blackboard.

words.example: Não posso falar, estou a trabalhar.

words.exampleTranslation: I did an internship at a company.
I have a job interview tomorrow.
The boss wants to talk to you.
words.proTip: Patrão/patroa = boss (informal). More colloquial than chefe. 'O patrão não gostou.'

words.example: O salário é pago no fim do mês.
words.exampleTranslation: The salary is paid at the end of the month.
I have the day off tomorrow.
words.proTip: Folga = day off. 'Tenho folga amanhã' = I have the day off tomorrow. 'Dia de folga.'

words.exampleTranslation: On holiday I went to the Algarve.

words.example: O meu pai está na reforma.
words.proTip: Reforma = retirement. 'Estar na reforma' = to be retired. Portuguese retire around 66.

categories.title: Health & Body
categories.description: Body parts, health, symptoms, and medical vocabulary

words.proTip: Cabeça = head. Feminine: a cabeça. 'Dói-me a cabeça' = My head hurts (lit. It hurts me the head).
Olho (eye) → olhos (eyes). Irregular plural! 'Tenho os olhos castanhos' = I have brown eyes.
Nariz = nose. One nose, same form. 'O nariz está entupido' = My nose is blocked.
Boca = mouth. Feminine. 'Abre a boca' = Open your mouth (doctor/dentist).
Orelha = ear. 'Dói-me a orelha' = My ear hurts. Orelha can also mean ear (of corn).
Dente → dentes (tooth/teeth). 'Dor de dentes' = toothache. Dentista = dentist.
Cabelo = hair (as a whole). Usually singular: 'o cabelo.' 'O cabelo está molhado.'
Mão (hand) → mãos (hands). Irregular! The only -ão word that becomes -ãos.
Braço → braços. 'Parti o braço' = I broke my arm. Braço = arm; abraço = hug.
Perna = leg. 'Dói-me a perna' = My leg hurts. Feminine.
Pé (foot) → pés (feet). Irregular! 'Os pés estão frios' = My feet are cold.
Costas = back. Always plural! 'Tenho dores nas costas' = I have back pain.
Barriga = belly/stomach. Informal. 'Dói-me a barriga' = My stomach hurts. Estômago is more formal.
Dedo = finger or toe. 'Dedo do pé' = toe. 'Dedo da mão' = finger. Same word for both.

words.exampleTranslation: I'm in a lot of pain.
words.proTip: Dor = pain. Feminine: 'tenho muita dor.' 'Dói-me' = it hurts me — use with body parts.

words.example: Tenho uma dor de cabeça forte.
words.proTip: Dor de cabeça = headache. 'Tenho uma dor de cabeça forte' = I have a bad headache.
Febre = fever. 'Tenho febre' = I have a fever. Go to farmácia first — they can advise.

words.exampleTranslation: I have a cold. (False friend: in Portuguese constipação means cold, not constipation.)
words.proTip: FALSE FRIEND! 'Constipação' = cold (illness), NOT constipation! For constipation: 'obstipação' or 'prisão de ventre.'
Gripe = flu. 'Apanhei uma gripe' = I caught the flu. Vaccination: 'vacina da gripe.'

words.exampleTranslation: I've had a cough for a week.
words.proTip: Tosse = cough. 'Tenho tosse' = I have a cough. Feminine.

words.exampleTranslation: I take one pill a day.
words.proTip: Comprimido = pill/tablet. 'Tomar um comprimido' = to take a pill. De manhã/à noite = morning/evening.

words.exampleTranslation: The medicine is at the pharmacy.
I'm sick, I'm not going to work.
words.proTip: Doente = sick/ill. 'Estou doente' = I'm sick. Can also mean 'patient' (o doente).
Saudável = healthy. 'Vida saudável' = healthy lifestyle. Comida saudável = healthy food.
Cansado/cansada = tired. Agrees with speaker: men say cansado, women cansada.

words.example: Tenho uma consulta no médico às três.
words.exampleTranslation: I have a doctor's appointment at three.

words.proTip: 'Dói-me' = it hurts me. 'Dói-me a cabeça' = I have a headache. The 'me' is the indirect object.

words.exampleTranslation: I hope you get better soon.
words.proTip: Melhorar = to get better. 'Espero que melhores em breve' = I hope you get better soon.

words.exampleTranslation: The doctor gave me a prescription.

words.example: Fui às urgências ontem à noite.
words.exampleTranslation: I went to A&E last night.
words.proTip: Urgências = A&E / ER. 'Fui às urgências' = I went to A&E. For emergencies, go to hospital.
Penso = plaster/band-aid. 'Penso rápido' = sticking plaster. At the farmácia.

words.exampleTranslation: I have a lot of backache.
I'm not going to work, I'm sick.
words.proTip: 'Estou doente' = I'm sick. Common excuse: 'Não vou trabalhar, estou doente.'

words.exampleTranslation: It hurts here in my arm.

words.example: Tenho febre e dor de cabeça.
words.exampleTranslation: I have a fever and a headache.
words.proTip: 'Tenho febre' = I have a fever. Thermometer = termómetro. 38°+ is febre.

words.exampleTranslation: He was taken to the emergency room.

words.example: Estou constipado, vou ficar em casa.
words.exampleTranslation: I have a cold, I'll stay at home.

words.example: Tenho uma dor de cabeça forte.
A criança tem dor de barriga.

categories.title: Shopping & Money
categories.description: Shops, prices, payments, and everyday transactions

words.exampleTranslation: I don't have any money on me.
words.proTip: Dinheiro = money. 'Trocar dinheiro' = exchange money. Portugal uses euros (euros).
'Qual é o preço?' = What's the price? For bargaining (rare in Portugal except at markets): 'Pode fazer melhor preço?' (Can you do a better price?)
Barato = cheap. 'É barato' = It's cheap. Supermercados have 'preços baixos' (low prices).
Caro = expensive. 'Lisboa está cara' = Lisbon is expensive. Renda (rent) is often 'cara.'
'Tem troco?' = Do you have change? Small shops in Portugal sometimes struggle with large notes. 'Fique com o troco' = Keep the change.

words.exampleTranslation: There is a discount for students.
words.proTip: Desconto = discount. 'Há desconto?' = Is there a discount? 'Saldos' = sales (January, July).

words.exampleTranslation: There is an ATM on the corner.
words.proTip: Multibanco = Portuguese ATMs. You can pay bills, top up phones, buy train tickets. More than just cash — it's the national payment system.

words.exampleTranslation: I forgot my wallet at home.

words.proTip: Loja = shop. 'Loja de roupa' = clothes shop. Shops close 7–8pm, some close for lunch.

words.exampleTranslation: We're going to the shopping centre.
I buy meat at the butcher's.
I buy bread at the grocery shop.
I need to go to the shoe shop.
I bought the book at the bookshop.
They sell fruit at the market.
How much is it to pay?
I don't want to spend much.
There is a promotion this week.

words.example: Tens uma moeda de um euro?
words.exampleTranslation: Do you have a one euro coin?
I only have twenty euro notes.
Can you give me change for ten euros?
I want to return this coat.
Can I try on this shirt?

words.example: O balanço da conta está positivo.
Estou a poupar para as férias.

categories.title: Nature & Animals
categories.description: Animals, plants, landscapes, and the natural world

words.exampleTranslation: The dog is in the garden.
words.proTip: Cão → cães (dog/dogs). Irregular plural! Very common pet. 'O cão' = the dog.
Gato = cat. Gato/gatos. 'O gato está a dormir' = The cat is sleeping. Popular pets.

words.exampleTranslation: The bird sings in the morning.
words.proTip: Pássaro = bird. Portugal has diverse birdlife. 'Ouço os pássaros' = I hear the birds.

words.exampleTranslation: The fish lives in the aquarium.
words.proTip: Peixe = fish. Same singular/plural in some contexts. Portugal eats a lot of peixe — coastal nation.

words.exampleTranslation: The horses are in the field.
A butterfly landed on the flower.

words.proTip: Árvore = tree. Feminine. 'Sob a árvore' = under the tree. Portuguese love their olive trees (oliveiras).

words.example: Comprei flores para a minha mãe.
words.exampleTranslation: I bought flowers for my mother.
words.proTip: Flor = flower. Feminine. 'As flores estão bonitas' = The flowers are beautiful. Portugal has stunning wildflowers.
Rio = river. Tejo, Douro, Mondego — Portugal's main rivers. 'À beira-rio' = by the river.
Mar = sea. Masculine: o mar. 'Vou ao mar' = I'm going to the sea. Portugal = 800+ km of coast.
Montanha = mountain. Serra da Estrela is the highest. 'Fazer uma caminhada na montanha.'
Campo = countryside/field. 'Viver no campo' = to live in the countryside. Alentejo = vast campos.

words.example: O lobo ibérico está em perigo.

words.exampleTranslation: I saw a fox in the countryside.

words.example: Há golfinhos na costa do Algarve.
words.exampleTranslation: There are dolphins on the Algarve coast.

words.example: O pastor leva as ovelhas ao monte.
words.exampleTranslation: The shepherd takes the sheep to the hills.

words.example: O porco preto alentejano é famoso.
words.exampleTranslation: The Alentejo black pig is famous.

words.example: A areia da praia é branca.
A água vem de uma nascente.
words.exampleTranslation: The water comes from a spring.
The village is on a hill.

words.example: O pôr do sol no Algarve é incrível.
words.exampleTranslation: The sunset in the Algarve is incredible.

words.example: Fomos dar um passeio à beira-mar.
words.exampleTranslation: We went for a walk by the sea.

words.example: Vamos ver o pôr do sol.
Acordámos para ver o nascer do sol.
words.exampleTranslation: We woke up to see the sunrise.

categories.title: Emotions & Personality
categories.description: Feelings, moods, character traits, and describing people

words.proTip: Feliz = happy. 'Estou feliz' = I'm happy. Feliz aniversário! = Happy birthday!
Triste = sad. 'Estou triste' = I'm sad. Fado is música triste — saudade in song form.
Zangado = angry. 'Estou zangado' = I'm angry. Menos forte que 'furioso.'
Preocupado = worried. 'Estou preocupado' = I'm worried. Common state!

words.example: Fico nervoso antes de falar em público.
words.exampleTranslation: I get nervous before speaking in public.
words.proTip: Nervoso = nervous. 'Estou nervoso' = I'm nervous. Agrees: nervoso/nervosa.

words.exampleTranslation: I was surprised by the news.
words.proTip: Surpreso = surprised. 'Fiquei surpreso' = I was surprised. Surpreso/surpresa.

words.example: Os meus pais estão orgulhosos de mim.
words.exampleTranslation: My parents are proud of me.

words.proTip: Calmo = calm. 'Fica calmo' = Stay calm. Portuguese value being calmo.
False friend alert! 'Simpático' does NOT mean 'sympathetic' — it means 'nice/friendly/likeable.' To say sympathetic, use 'compreensivo.' This is one of the most common mistakes English speakers make.
'Chateado' is milder than 'zangado' (angry). 'Que chato!' (how annoying!) is one of the most common Portuguese expressions.

Portugal's most famous word — there's no exact English translation. 'Tenho saudades tuas' = I miss you. It's deeper than missing; it's a bittersweet longing. Central to Portuguese culture and fado music.
Amor = love. 'Amor' as address = honey/darling. 'O meu amor' = my love. Central to Portuguese expression.

words.exampleTranslation: I was relieved with the result.

words.example: A minha avó é muito generosa.

words.exampleTranslation: What a joy to see you!
He felt a lot of rage.

words.example: Tenho muito orgulho no meu filho.
words.exampleTranslation: I'm very proud of my son.

words.proTip: Cansado/cansada = tired. Agrees with speaker: men say cansado, women cansada.

words.exampleTranslation: I was scared by the noise.
I was surprised by the news.

categories.title: Colloquial & Slang
categories.description: Informal expressions, fillers, and everyday slang used in spoken European Portuguese

words.proTip: Bora = let's go. From 'vamos embora.' 'Bora!' = Let's go! Very informal, young people.
Tá = contraction of 'está.' 'Tá bem' = Okay. 'Tá bom' = That's fine. Very informal writing/speech.
Tranquilo = cool/no problem. 'Está tranquilo' = It's all good. Laid-back response.

words.exampleTranslation: You're right, it's better this way.
It was like a party, you know?

words.proTip: Cena = thing/stuff. 'Essa cena' = that thing. 'Que cena!' = What a thing! Very informal.
'Gajo' and 'gaja' are very informal — like 'dude' and 'chick.' Fine with friends but avoid in formal situations. 'Aquele gajo' = That guy. Not offensive, just casual.

words.example: Fica à vontade, estás em casa.

words.exampleTranslation: Come on, I can't believe it!
words.proTip: Epá = hey/man/dude. Filler word. 'Epá, não acredito!' = Man, I can't believe it! Very Portuguese.

words.exampleTranslation: Hey bro, shall we go to the café?

words.proTip: Slang: 'bué' = a lot, very. 'Bué fixe!' = Super cool! Very Portuguese. Used by young people but understood by all.

words.exampleTranslation: Don't worry, I'll take care of it.

words.example: A malta quer ir ao cinema.
words.exampleTranslation: The group wants to go to the cinema.

words.proTip: Giro = cute/cool. 'Que giro!' = How cute! Very Portuguese. Can describe people or things.

words.example: O teu irmão é muito porreiro.
words.proTip: Porreiro = cool/great. Slightly older slang. 'Está porreiro' = It's great. Lisbon/Porto usage.

words.exampleTranslation: I think I messed everything up.

words.example: Havia montes de gente na festa.
words.exampleTranslation: There were loads of people at the party.

categories.title: Technology & Internet
categories.description: Telemóvel, ecrã, palavra-passe — devices, apps, and digital life.

words.exampleTranslation: I forgot my laptop at home.
words.proTip: In Portugal, 'portátil' is always used for laptop. Never say 'laptop' — although people will understand you.

words.example: O meu filho usa o tablet para desenhar.
words.exampleTranslation: My son uses the tablet to draw.

words.example: O rato do computador não funciona.
words.proTip: Yes, it's the same word as 'mouse' the animal — 'rato.' Context makes it clear.
'Auscultadores' is the standard European Portuguese word. 'Auriculares' is also used, especially for earbuds.

words.exampleTranslation: Play the music on the speaker.
words.proTip: 'Coluna' also means 'column' or 'spine' — context tells you which. For audio: 'coluna de som' or just 'coluna.'

words.example: A câmara do telemóvel é muito boa.
words.exampleTranslation: The phone camera is very good.

words.example: O meu telemóvel ficou sem bateria.
words.exampleTranslation: My phone ran out of battery.

words.example: Tens um carregador que me emprestes?
words.exampleTranslation: Do you have a charger you can lend me?
I don't have internet at home.
words.proTip: In European Portuguese, 'internet' is feminine: 'a internet.' You'll hear 'a net' colloquially.

words.example: Qual é a palavra-passe do Wi-Fi?
A rede está muito lenta hoje.
words.exampleTranslation: The network is very slow today.
I found a very useful website.
words.proTip: 'Site' (from English) is commonly used in PT-PT. You can also say 'sítio web' or 'página web,' but 'site' is the most common.

words.exampleTranslation: I need to download the app.
words.proTip: In European Portuguese, 'descarregar' = download and 'carregar' = upload. Never use 'baixar' — that's Brazilian Portuguese.

words.english: to upload / to charge / to load
words.example: Vou carregar as fotos para a nuvem.
words.exampleTranslation: I'm going to upload the photos to the cloud.
words.proTip: 'Carregar' has multiple meanings: upload (files), charge (battery), load (a page), press (a button). Context is key.

words.example: Passo muito tempo a navegar na internet.
words.exampleTranslation: I spend a lot of time browsing the internet.
Have you already downloaded the app?
words.proTip: In European Portuguese, always say 'aplicação' — never 'aplicativo' (that's Brazilian).

words.exampleTranslation: Are you on any social media?
I'm going to look at your profile.
Do you want to follow my page?
Can you share this link with me?
words.proTip: 'Partilhar' is European Portuguese. In Brazil they say 'compartilhar.'

words.example: Vou publicar uma foto do jantar.
words.exampleTranslation: I'm going to post a photo of dinner.
words.proTip: In PT-PT, 'publicar' = to post online. Never use 'postar' — that's Brazilian Portuguese.

words.example: Deixei um comentário na tua foto.
words.exampleTranslation: I left a comment on your photo.
Send me a message when you arrive.
I received a notification on my phone.
I'm going to search on Google.

words.example: Copia o endereço e cola aqui.
words.exampleTranslation: Copy the address and paste it here.

words.example: Não te esqueças de guardar o ficheiro.
words.exampleTranslation: Don't forget to save the file.

words.proTip: 'Apagar' also means 'to turn off' (a light) or 'to erase.' 'Apagar um ficheiro' = delete a file.

words.exampleTranslation: I need to update the system.
Can you send me the link?

words.proTip: European Portuguese always says 'palavra-passe.' Never use 'senha' — that's Brazilian Portuguese.

words.example: Qual é o teu nome de utilizador?

words.exampleTranslation: You have to log in first.

words.example: Não te esqueças de terminar sessão.
Abre o ficheiro que te enviei.
words.exampleTranslation: Open the file I sent you.
words.proTip: In PT-PT, always say 'ficheiro' for a digital file. 'Arquivo' means archive. In Brazil, 'arquivo' is used for both.

words.exampleTranslation: Do you want to take a photo?
words.proTip: 'Fotografia' is the formal word; 'foto' is the everyday short form. Both are feminine: 'a fotografia,' 'a foto.'

words.example: Viste o vídeo que te enviei?
words.exampleTranslation: Did you see the video I sent you?

relatedWords.meaning: to turn off / to hang up

words.proTip: 'Ligar' = turn on (device), call someone, or connect. 'Desligar' = turn off or hang up. 'Liga-me!' = Call me!

words.english: to turn off / to hang up
words.example: Desliga o telemóvel durante o filme.
words.exampleTranslation: Turn off your phone during the movie.

categories.title: Clothing & Appearance
categories.description: Camisa, sapatos, vestido — clothing, style, and describing how people look.

words.exampleTranslation: I'm going to wear the blue shirt.

words.proTip: 'Camisola' in PT-PT means sweater/jumper. In Brazil, 'camisola' means nightgown — very different!

words.exampleTranslation: Don't go out without a coat.
Bring the jacket, it might rain.

words.example: Ele usou um colete por cima da camisa.
words.exampleTranslation: He wore a waistcoat over the shirt.

words.example: Preciso de um fato para a entrevista.
words.exampleTranslation: I need a suit for the interview.
words.proTip: 'Fato' = suit (formal). 'Fato de banho' = swimsuit. 'Fato de treino' = tracksuit. In Brazil, 'fato' means 'fact' — in PT-PT it's primarily 'suit.'
Even though it's clothing worn by women, 'vestido' is masculine: 'o vestido.'
'Calças' is always plural in Portuguese — you never say 'calça' (singular) for trousers.

words.exampleTranslation: In summer I always wear shorts.

words.example: A saia preta combina com tudo.
words.exampleTranslation: The black skirt goes with everything.

words.example: As calças de ganga são muito confortáveis.
words.proTip: 'Ganga' = denim. In PT-PT, jeans are always 'calças de ganga.' You might hear 'jeans' too, but 'calças de ganga' is the proper term.

words.example: Vou calçar os ténis para correr.
words.exampleTranslation: I'm going to put on my trainers to run.
words.proTip: In PT-PT, 'ténis' means both the sport (tennis) and sneakers/trainers. 'Sapatilhas' is also used for trainers.

words.exampleTranslation: In winter I always wear boots.
At the beach I wear sandals.

words.example: Em casa ando sempre de chinelos.
words.exampleTranslation: At home I always wear slippers.
words.proTip: 'Chinelos' can mean both slippers (indoor) and flip-flops (beach). Context clarifies.

words.example: Põe o chapéu, está muito sol.
words.exampleTranslation: Put on your hat, it's very sunny.

words.example: Leva um lenço para o pescoço.
words.exampleTranslation: Bring a scarf for your neck.

words.example: Precisas de um cinto com estas calças.
words.exampleTranslation: You need a belt with these trousers.

words.proTip: 'Óculos' is always plural. 'Usar óculos' = to wear glasses.
'Relógio' means both wristwatch and clock. 'Relógio de pulso' = wristwatch. 'Relógio de parede' = wall clock.

words.example: Ela usa sempre o mesmo colar.
words.exampleTranslation: She always wears the same necklace.
words.proTip: Same spelling as 'colar' (to paste/to glue) — context makes it clear. As a noun with article: 'o colar' = the necklace.

words.exampleTranslation: The bracelet is made of silver.

words.example: Que anel bonito! É de ouro?
words.exampleTranslation: What a beautiful ring! Is it gold?

words.example: Leva a mala, tens lá tudo.
words.exampleTranslation: Bring the bag, you have everything in there.
words.proTip: 'Mala' in PT-PT means handbag/purse (everyday) or suitcase (travel). 'Mala de mão' = handbag, 'mala de viagem' = suitcase.

words.example: Estás muito elegante com esse fato.
words.exampleTranslation: You look very smart in that suit.
I prefer a more casual style.
I prefer plain T-shirts, without designs.

words.example: Aquela camisola às riscas é gira.

words.exampleTranslation: Do you have a polka-dot skirt?

words.example: Despe o casaco, está calor aqui.
words.exampleTranslation: Take off your coat, it's hot in here.
Put your shoes on, we're going out.
words.proTip: 'Calçar' is specifically for footwear. 'Vestir' is for clothing. Portuguese distinguishes the two — you never 'vestir' shoes.

words.example: Em casa, descalço os sapatos à entrada.
words.exampleTranslation: At home, I take off my shoes at the door.

words.proTip: 'Provar' = try on (clothes) or taste (food). 'Experimentar' also works for both, but 'provar' is more common for clothes in shops.

words.example: Esta gravata não combina com a camisa.
words.exampleTranslation: This tie doesn't go with the shirt.
words.proTip: 'Combinar' also means 'to arrange/agree' (e.g., 'Vamos combinar um dia' = Let's arrange a day). For clothes: 'combinar com' = to match/go with.

words.exampleTranslation: I need to buy new clothes.
words.proTip: 'Roupa' is always singular in Portuguese, even when referring to multiple items. 'Muita roupa' = many clothes.

words.exampleTranslation: The keys are in the pocket.
There's a button missing on this shirt.

words.example: O fecho do casaco está preso.
words.proTip: 'Fecho' or 'fecho éclair' — both are used in PT-PT for zipper.

words.exampleTranslation: What shoe size do you wear?
words.proTip: For shoes: 'número' (Que número calças? = What size?). For clothes: 'tamanho.' Two different words!

words.example: Tens de usar gravata no escritório?
words.exampleTranslation: Do you have to wear a tie at the office?

words.example: Leva roupa interior suficiente para a viagem.
words.exampleTranslation: Bring enough underwear for the trip.

words.english: it suits you / it looks good on you
words.exampleTranslation: That dress looks great on you!
words.proTip: 'Fica-te bem' (informal you) / 'Fica-lhe bem' (formal). To say it looks bad: 'Não te fica bem' or 'Fica-te mal.'
